comment: shortening sentence on religion, adding a clarification that this specific formulation is Catholic; there may be a better solution to this, but this is at least a stop-gap

[[File:DickseeRomeoandJuliet.jpg|thumb|upright|Archetypal lovers [[Romeo and Juliet]] portrayed by [[Frank Bernard Dicksee|Frank Dicksee]].]]
 
[[File:DickseeRomeoandJuliet.jpg|thumb|upright|Archetypal lovers [[Romeo and Juliet]] portrayed by [[Frank Bernard Dicksee|Frank Dicksee]].]]
−
'''Love''' is the [[emotion]] of strong [[affection]] and personal [[attachment (psychology)|attachment]].<ref name="oxford">''Oxford Illustrated American Dictionary'' (1998) + ''Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary'' (2000)</ref> In philosophical context, love is a [[virtue]] representing all of human [[kindness]], [[compassion]], and [[affection]]. In [[religious]] context, love is not just a virtue, but the basis for all ''[[being]]'' ("[[God is love]]"<ref>[[Deus Caritas Est]], Roman Catholic encyclical by Pope Benedict XVI</ref>), and the foundation for all [[divine law]] ([[Golden Rule]]). Love may also be described as actions towards others (or oneself) based on compassion.<ref>Fromm, Eric; "The Art of Loving", Harper Perennial (1956), Original English Version, ISBN-10: 0060958286 ISBN-13: 978-0060958282</ref> Or as actions towards others based on affection.<ref>Fromm, Eric; "The Art of Loving", Harper Perennial (1956), Original English Version, ISBN-10: 0060958286 ISBN-13: 978-0060958282</ref>
+
'''Love''' is the [[emotion]] of strong [[affection]] and personal [[attachment (psychology)|attachment]].<ref name="oxford">''Oxford Illustrated American Dictionary'' (1998) + ''Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary'' (2000)</ref> In philosophical context, love is a [[virtue]] representing all of human [[kindness]], [[compassion]], and [[affection]]. In some [[religious]] contexts, love is not just a virtue, but the basis for all ''[[being]]'', as in the Roman Catholic phrase, "[[God is love]]"<ref>[[Deus Caritas Est]], Roman Catholic encyclical by Pope Benedict XVI</ref>. Love may also be described as actions towards others (or oneself) based on compassion.<ref>Fromm, Eric; "The Art of Loving", Harper Perennial (1956), Original English Version, ISBN-10: 0060958286 ISBN-13: 978-0060958282</ref> Or as actions towards others based on affection.<ref>Fromm, Eric; "The Art of Loving", Harper Perennial (1956), Original English Version, ISBN-10: 0060958286 ISBN-13: 978-0060958282</ref>
     
<!--various usages-->The word ''[[wikt:en:love|love]]'' can refer to a variety of different feelings, states, and attitudes, ranging from generic [[pleasure]] ("I loved that meal") to intense [[interpersonal attraction]] ("I love my partner"). "Love" can also refer specifically to the passionate desire and intimacy of [[romance (love)|romantic love]], to the [[sex]]ual love of [[eros]] (cf. [[Greek words for love]]), to the emotional closeness of [[familial love|familial]] love, or to the [[platonic love]] that defines [[friendship]],<ref name="PlatonicSchool">{{cite book |last=Kristeller |first=Paul Oskar |title=Renaissance Thought and the Arts: Collected Essays |publisher=Princeton University |year=1980 |isbn=0-691-02010-8}}</ref>
 
<!--various usages-->The word ''[[wikt:en:love|love]]'' can refer to a variety of different feelings, states, and attitudes, ranging from generic [[pleasure]] ("I loved that meal") to intense [[interpersonal attraction]] ("I love my partner"). "Love" can also refer specifically to the passionate desire and intimacy of [[romance (love)|romantic love]], to the [[sex]]ual love of [[eros]] (cf. [[Greek words for love]]), to the emotional closeness of [[familial love|familial]] love, or to the [[platonic love]] that defines [[friendship]],<ref name="PlatonicSchool">{{cite book |last=Kristeller |first=Paul Oskar |title=Renaissance Thought and the Arts: Collected Essays |publisher=Princeton University |year=1980 |isbn=0-691-02010-8}}</ref>
